title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 1. (1) These Rules, which may be cited as the Circuit Court Rules
text_raw:
1. (1) These Rules, which may be cited as the Circuit Court Rules 

(Interrogatories) 2025, shall come into operation on the 13th day of June, 2025. 

(2) These Rules shall be construed together with the Circuit Court Rules 2001 

to 2025. 

(3) The Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2024 as amended by these Rules may be 

cited as the Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2025.
text_norm: 1 (1) rule may cited circuit court rule (interrogatories) 2025 shall come operation 13th day june 2025 (2) rule shall construed together circuit court rule 2001 2025 (3) circuit court rule 2001 2024 amended rule may cited circuit court rule 2001 2025

text_raw:
2. These Rules shall apply in proceedings commenced from the date on which 

these Rules come into operation.

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 3. The Circuit Court Rules are amended by the substitution for rule 9 of Order
text_raw:
3. The Circuit Court Rules are amended by the substitution for rule 9 of Order 

32 of the following provisions: 

“Interrogatories
text_norm: 3 circuit court rule amended substitution rule 9 order 32 following provision interrogatory

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 9. Subject to rules 10 and 11, a party (the “interrogating party”) may at
text_raw:
9. Subject to rules 10 and 11, a party (the “interrogating party”) may at 
any time after delivering his or her Civil Bill or Defence, as the case may 
be, and prior to the service of Notice of Trial, without the prior leave of 
the Court, deliver interrogatories in writing for the examination of any 
other party to the proceedings (the “interrogated party”).
text_norm: 9 subject rule 10 11 party (the interrogating party ) may time delivering civil bill defence case may prior service notice trial without prior leave court deliver interrogatory writing examination party proceeding (the interrogated party )

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 10. (1) Interrogatories addressed to one party only and answers to such
text_raw:
10. (1) Interrogatories addressed to one party only and answers to such 

interrogatories must be copied to every other party. 

(2) Where the interrogated party is a body corporate or an 
unincorporated body of persons, the interrogatories shall be answered by 
the secretary or such other person as is nominated by the interrogated 
party, but where the interrogating party requires a particular other officer, 
member, or employee of the interrogated party to answer particular 
interrogatories, he or she shall apply by motion on notice to the 
interrogated party for an order permitting such a requirement. 

(3) Interrogatories shall be in the Form No. 57A in the Schedule of 
Forms and shall include a brief statement of the reasons why answers to 
each interrogatory or group of interrogatories are necessary for disposing 
fairly of the cause or matter or for saving costs. 

(4) Without limiting the grounds on which objection may be made, 

interrogatories: 

(a) must be confined to questions as to facts in issue in the 
proceedings or facts reasonably relevant to establish facts in 
issue in the proceedings, but excluding questions concerning 
the evidence by which any fact might be proved; 

 
 
 
 4 [200] 

(b) must be confined to questions of fact the answer to each of 
which is likely to be within the knowledge of the person 
required to answer having, where appropriate, made any 
reasonably necessary inquiries; 

(c) must be confined to questions of fact which are amenable to 
answer by an affirmative, negative, or short statement of fact 
without narrative; 

(d) must be confined to questions of fact which are necessary 
either for disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for saving 
costs.
text_norm: 10 (1) interrogatory addressed one party answer interrogatory must copied every party (2) interrogated party body corporate unincorporated body person interrogatory shall answered secretary person nominated interrogated party interrogating party requires particular officer member employee interrogated party answer particular interrogatory shall apply motion notice interrogated party order permitting requirement (3) interrogatory shall form no 57a schedule form shall include brief statement reason answer interrogatory group interrogatory necessary disposing fairly cause matter saving cost (4) without limiting ground objection may made interrogatory (a) must confined question fact issue proceeding fact reasonably relevant establish fact issue proceeding excluding question concerning evidence fact might proved 4 200 (b) must confined question fact answer likely within knowledge person required answer appropriate made reasonably necessary inquiry (c) must confined question fact amenable answer affirmative negative short statement fact without narrative (d) must confined question fact necessary either disposing fairly cause matter saving cost

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 11. Notwithstanding rule 9, a party may not, without an order of the
text_raw:
11. Notwithstanding rule 9, a party may not, without an order of the 

Court or County Registrar: 

(a) 

deliver interrogatories exceeding 20 in number to any other 
party; or 

(b) deliver more than one set of interrogatories to the same party.
text_norm: 11 notwithstanding rule 9 party may without order court county registrar (a) deliver interrogatory exceeding 20 number party (b) deliver one set interrogatory party

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 12. (1) The interrogated party shall, within 21 days of delivery or such
text_raw:
12. (1) The interrogated party shall, within 21 days of delivery or such 
other time as is agreed or directed by the Court or the County Registrar, 
deliver to the interrogating party and file a notice setting out the grounds 
of any objection to any interrogatory which shall include, where relevant, 
details of any other means by which the interrogated party is willing to 
address the matter raised in the interrogatory concerned (including, 
without limitation, by delivering further particulars, by making an 
admission, or by producing documents). 

(2) The interrogated party shall, at the same time, deliver to the 
interrogating party and file an affidavit, answering those interrogatories 
which the interrogated party is willing to answer, and verifying any facts 
relied on in any notice of objection delivered, and a copy of any such 
notice shall be exhibited to the affidavit.
text_norm: 12 (1) interrogated party shall within 21 day delivery time agreed directed court county registrar deliver interrogating party file notice setting ground objection interrogatory shall include relevant detail mean interrogated party willing address matter raised interrogatory concerned (including without limitation delivering particular making admission producing documents) (2) interrogated party shall time deliver interrogating party file affidavit answering interrogatory interrogated party willing answer verifying fact relied notice objection delivered copy notice shall exhibited affidavit

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 13. Grounds of objection to an interrogatory shall be set out concisely.
text_raw:
13. Grounds of objection to an interrogatory shall be set out concisely. 
Such grounds may include that the interrogatory does not comply with the 
requirements of rule 10, or is not sufficiently material at that stage, or is 
not bona fide for the purpose of the proceedings, or any other proper 
ground of objection.
text_norm: 13 ground objection interrogatory shall set concisely ground may include interrogatory comply requirement rule 10 sufficiently material stage bona fide purpose proceeding proper ground objection

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 14. An affidavit in answer to interrogatories shall be in the Form No.
text_raw:
14. An affidavit in answer to interrogatories shall be in the Form No. 
57B in the Schedule of Forms and shall include the text of each 
interrogatory prior to the answer or other response thereto.
text_norm: 14 affidavit answer interrogatory shall form no 57b schedule form shall include text interrogatory prior answer response thereto

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 15.(1) Where:
text_raw:
15.(1) Where: 

 
 
 
 
 
 [200] 5 

(a) 

(b) 

the interrogating party does not accept the sufficiency of the 
answers provided (including, where relevant, any proposal to 
address by other means a matter raised in an interrogatory), 
or does not accept any objection made, or 
the interrogated party fails or omits to answer any 
interrogatory, 

the interrogating party may apply to the Court or the County Registrar, 
within 14 days of the delivery of the interrogated party’s affidavit and any 
notice of objection (or, as the case may be, within 14 days after the expiry 
of the time allowed for such delivery), by motion on notice to compel the 
delivery of answers, or further answers, or for any other appropriate relief. 

(2) Such application shall be grounded upon an affidavit.

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 16. The interrogated party may rely on the affidavit in answer in
text_raw:
16. The interrogated party may rely on the affidavit in answer in 
opposing any such application, but is at liberty to deliver and file a further 
affidavit on the application.
text_norm: 16 interrogated party may rely affidavit answer opposing application liberty deliver file affidavit application

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 17. On the hearing of an application under rule 15, the Court or the
text_raw:
17. On the hearing of an application under rule 15, the Court or the 

County Registrar may: 

(a) make an order requiring the interrogated party to answer or 
answer further, as the case may be, either by affidavit or by 
viva voce examination, as the Court or the County Registrar 
directs, 

(b) determine that the interrogated party is not required to 

answer: 
(i) any interrogatory which does not comply with the 

requirements of rule 10; 

(ii) any 

interrogatories which have been delivered 
unreasonably or vexatiously, or which are prolix, 
oppressive, unnecessary, or scandalous; 

(iii) any interrogatories the imposition of a requirement to 
answer which might prejudice a fair hearing of the issues 
between the parties, 

and may make such further or other order on the application as is just, 
including an order for the delivery of fresh interrogatories, an order for 
the delivery of further particulars, or an order for the production of 
documents.
text_norm: 17 hearing application rule 15 court county registrar may (a) make order requiring interrogated party answer answer case may either affidavit viva voce examination court county registrar directs (b) determine interrogated party required answer (i) interrogatory comply requirement rule 10 (ii) interrogatory delivered unreasonably vexatiously prolix oppressive unnecessary scandalous (iii) interrogatory imposition requirement answer might prejudice fair hearing issue party may make order application including order delivery fresh interrogatory order delivery particular order production document

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 19. Any person not a party to the cause or action before the Court who
text_raw:
19. Any person not a party to the cause or action before the Court who 
appears to the Court or to the County Registrar to be likely to have or to 
have had in his or her possession, custody, or power any documents which 
are relevant to an issue arising or likely to arise out of the cause or action, 
or is or is likely to be in a position to give evidence relevant to any such 
issue, may by leave of the Court or the County Registrar, upon the 
application of any party to the said cause or action, be directed by order 
of the Court or the County Registrar to answer such interrogatories, or to 
make discovery of such documents, or to permit inspection of such 
documents, provided that, in advance of the issuing of such notice of 
motion, such discovery shall be requested to be made voluntarily in 
accordance with the provisions of Rule 1 hereof, the request for voluntary 
discovery being made to the person against whom discovery is sought and 
the other parties to the proceedings. The provisions of this Order shall 
apply mutatis mutandis as if the said Order of the Court or the County 
Registrar had been directed to a party to the said cause or action, provided 
always that the party seeking such order shall indemnify such person in 
respect of all costs thereby reasonably incurred by such person, and such 
costs borne by the said party shall be deemed to be costs of that party in 
the proceedings.”
text_norm: 19 person party cause action court appears court county registrar likely possession custody power document relevant issue arising likely arise cause action likely position give evidence relevant issue may leave court county registrar upon application party said cause action directed order court county registrar answer interrogatory make discovery document permit inspection document provided advance issuing notice motion discovery shall requested made voluntarily accordance provision rule 1 hereof request voluntary discovery made person discovery sought party proceeding provision order shall apply mutatis mutandis said order court county registrar directed party said cause action provided always party seeking order shall indemnify person respect cost thereby reasonably incurred person cost borne said party shall deemed cost party proceeding

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: 4. The Forms 57A and 57B in the Schedule shall be inserted in the appropriate
text_raw:
4. The Forms 57A and 57B in the Schedule shall be inserted in the appropriate 

sequence in the Schedule of Forms annexed to the Circuit Court Rules. 

 
 
 [200] 7 

O. 32, r. 10(3) 

Schedule 

No. 57A 

INTERROGATORIES. 

[Title of action] 

Interrogatories on behalf of the [plaintiff or defendant] for the examination of the 
[defendant or plaintiff]. 

Reasons 

Answers to each of the following [groups of] interrogatories are necessary for 
disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for saving costs, for the following reasons. 

Question 1 (or Questions 1 to n inclusive): [Set out a brief statement of reasons] 

Question 2 (or Questions n to n inclusive): [Set out a brief statement of reasons], 
etc. 

Interrogatories 

[Set out the interrogatories, which must each comply with the requirements of 
Order 32, rules 9 to 11, as individual numbered questions, to a maximum of 20, 
unless otherwise permitted by order of the Court or County Registrar] 

Question 1.…………………………………..? 

Question 2.…………………………………..? 

Question 3.…………………………………..? 

Etc. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8 [200] 

AND TAKE NOTICE that if you fail to answer, or fail to answer sufficiently, 
on affidavit within 21 days of the delivery of these interrogatories, the [plaintiff 
or defendant] may apply to the Court or County Registrar pursuant to Order 32, 
rule 15 of the Circuit Court Rules for an order to compel the delivery of answers, 
or further answers, or for any other appropriate relief. 

Dated: ………………………………………….. 

________ 

 
 
 
 [200] 9 

_________ 

No. 57B 

O. 32, r. 14 

ANSWER TO INTERROGATORIES. 

[Title of action] 

The answer of the [defendant or plaintiff] to the interrogatories for his or her 
examination by the [plaintiff or defendant]. 

I, [state name and address] aged 18 years and upwards make oath and say as 
follows:— 

A. [Where the deponent answers on behalf of a body corporate or unincorporated 
body of persons, state the office or capacity in such body in which the deponent 
answers. In every case in which the deponent answers otherwise than from his or 
her own knowledge, state the deponent’s means of knowledge and any inquiries 
made by the deponent prior to answering.] 

The interrogatories and my answers (or, as the case may be, objections) to them 
are: 

Question 1.…………………………………..? 

Answer 1: 

Question 2.…………………………………..? 

Answer 2: 

Etc. 

[I beg to refer to the notice of objection delivered herein, upon a copy of which 
marked “A” I have signed my name prior to the swearing hereof. In support of the 
objections, I further say as follows: 

Set out any facts relied on in any notice of objection delivered] 

Sworn, etc. 

__________ 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10 [200]

title: by section 66 of the Courts of Justice Act 1924, section 70 of the Courts of Justice
heading: (This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These rules amend Order 32 of the Circuit Court Rules to remove the 
requirement to seek the court’s permission to deliver interrogatories where the 
number of interrogatories is not more than twenty, and insert Forms 57A and 
57B to the rules on interrogatories and answers to interrogatories. 

 
 
 
 
 [200] 11
